Visualize alpha diversity with scatterplots and trendlines.

Source: R/adiv_corrplot.r
adiv_corrplot.Rd

Visualize alpha diversity with scatterplots and trendlines.

Usage

adiv_corrplot(
  biom,
  x,
  adiv = "Shannon",
  layers = "tc",
  color.by = NULL,
  facet.by = NULL,
  limit.by = NULL,
  formula = y ~ x,
  engine = "lm",
  level = 0.95,
  trans = "none",
  caption = TRUE,
  ...
)

Arguments

biom

An rbiom-class object, or data coercible with as_rbiom().

x

A numeric metadata field to use for the x-axis. Required.

adiv

Alpha diversity metric(s) to use. Options are: "OTUs", "Shannon", "Chao1", "Simpson", and/or "InvSimpson". Set adiv=".all" to use all metrics. Default: "Shannon"

Multiple values allowed. Non-ambiguous abbreviations are allowed.

layers

One or more of c("trend", "confidence", "scatter", "name"). Single letter abbreviations are also accepted. For instance, c("trend", "scatter") is equivalent to c("t", "s") and "ts". See plot types for examples of each. Default: "tc"

color.by, facet.by, limit.by

Metadata columns to use for aesthetics and partitioning. See below for details. Default: NULL

formula

Relationship between variables. Default: y ~ x

engine

What type of trend model to fit to the data. Options are: "lm" (linear), "local" (uses loess or gam). Default: "lm"

level

The confidence level for calculating a confidence interval. Default: 0.95

trans

Transformation to apply. Options are: c("none", "rank", "log", "log1p", "sqrt"). "rank" is useful for correcting for non-normally distributions before applying regression statistics. Default: "none"

caption

Add methodology caption beneath the plot. Default: TRUE

...

Additional parameters to pass along to ggplot2 functions. Prefix a parameter name with either t. or s./pt. to ensure it gets passed to (and only to) geom_smooth or geom_point, respectively. For instance, s.size = 2 ensures only the scatterplot points have their size set to 2.

Value

A ggplot2 plot.
The computed data points and ggplot command are available as $data and $code, respectively.

Aesthetics and Partitions

Metadata can be used to flexibly subset, partition, and apply aesthetics when creating a plot. Common use cases are provided below. More thorough documentation is available at https://cmmr.github.io/rbiom.

  ## Colors ----------------------------
  color.by = "Body Site"
  color.by = list('Body Site' = "bright")
  color.by = list('Body Site' = c("Stool", "Saliva"))
  color.by = list('Body Site' = list('values' = c("Stool", "Saliva"), 'colors' = "bright"))
  color.by = list('Body Site' = c('Stool' = "blue", 'Saliva' = "green"))
  
  ## Facets ----------------------------
  facet.by = "Body Site"
  facet.by = c("Body Site", "Sex")
  facet.by = list('Body Site' = c("Stool", "Saliva"), "Sex")
  
  ## Limits ----------------------------
  limit.by = list('Sex' = "Male", 'Age' = c(20,40))
  limit.by = list('Body Site' = c("Saliva", "Anterior nares"), 'Age' = c(NA,35))

  • color.by - Any metadata column. (Max 1)

  • facet.by - Only categorical metadata column(s).

  • limit.by - Any metadata column(s).

All built-in color palettes are colorblind-friendly.

The available categorical palette names are: "okabe", "carto", "r4", "polychrome", "tol", "bright", "light", "muted", "vibrant", "tableau", "classic", "alphabet", "tableau20", "kelly", and "fishy".

The available numeric palette names are: "reds", "oranges", "greens", "purples", "grays", "acton", "bamako", "batlow", "bilbao", "buda", "davos", "devon", "grayC", "hawaii", "imola", "lajolla", "lapaz", "nuuk", "oslo", "tokyo", "turku", "bam", "berlin", "broc", "cork", "lisbon", "roma", "tofino", "vanimo", "vik"

See also

Other alpha_diversity: adiv_boxplot(), adiv_stats(), adiv_table()

Other visualization: adiv_boxplot(), bdiv_boxplot(), bdiv_corrplot(), bdiv_heatmap(), bdiv_ord_plot(), plot_heatmap(), rare_corrplot(), rare_multiplot(), rare_stacked(), taxa_boxplot(), taxa_corrplot(), taxa_heatmap(), taxa_stacked()

Examples

    library(rbiom)
    
    biom <- rarefy(hmp50)
    adiv_corrplot(biom, "age", color.by = list(Body = c("a", "sa")))

    adiv_corrplot(
      biom     = biom, 
      x        = "Age", 
      adiv     = c("OTUs", "Shannon", "Simpson"), 
      color.by = "Body Site", 
      facet.by = "Sex", 
      layers   = "trend" )
